or they are not. This is not a matter requiring consideration. Please make
this wording more precise.

@piiswrong
Please post a minimum reproduction. Including code, commit id and all compiler flags

the following is my module symbol file.
the compiler flags is same to the original one except setting cuda be used.
```python
def create_reid3_net(batch_size, proxy_num):
  data0 = mx.sym.Variable('data')
  proxy_yM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_yM')
  proxy_Z = mx.sym.Variable(name='proxy_Z_weight', 
                       shape=(proxy_num, 128), dtype=np.float32)
  proxy_ZM = mx.sym.Variable('proxy_ZM')
  args_all = None
  reid_feature, args_all = create_inception_resnet_v2(data0, namepre='part1', args=args_all)
  print reid_feature.name

  features = mx.sym.SliceChannel(reid_feature, axis=0, num_outputs=batch_size, name='features_slice')
  proxy_yMs = mx.sym.SliceChannel(proxy_yM, axis=0, num_outputs=batch_size, name='proxy_yM_slice')
  proxy_ZMs = mx.sym.SliceChannel(proxy_ZM, axis=0, num_outputs=batch_size, name='proxy_ZM_slice')
  proxy_ncas = []
  min_value = 10**-16
  norm_value = (84**0.5)/2
  print 'norm_value:', norm_value
  
  #norm
  if True:
    proxy_Znorm = mx.sym.sum_axis(proxy_Z**2, axis=1)
#    print proxy_Znorm.name
    proxy_Znorm = mx.sym.sqrt(proxy_Znorm)
    proxy_Znorm = mx.sym.Reshape(proxy_Znorm, shape=(-2, 1)) 
    proxy_Z = mx.sym.broadcast_div(proxy_Z, proxy_Znorm) * norm_value

  for bi in xrange(batch_size):
    one_feat = features[bi]
    
    #norm 
    if True:
      one_feat_norm = mx.sym.sqrt(mx.sym.sum(one_feat**2))
      one_feat_norm = mx.sym.Reshape(one_feat_norm, shape=(-2, 1)) 
      one_feat = mx.sym.broadcast_div(one_feat, one_feat_norm) * norm_value
    
    one_proxy_yM = proxy_yMs[bi]
    one_proxy_ZM = proxy_ZMs[bi]

    tzM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_ZM, shape=(-1,))
    z = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(one_feat, proxy_Z)
    z = mx.sym.square(z)
    z = mx.sym.sum_axis(z, axis=1)
    z = -z
    tyM = mx.sym.Reshape(one_proxy_yM, shape=(-1, 1)) 
    one_proxy_y = mx.sym.broadcast_mul(tyM, proxy_Z)
    one_proxy_y = mx.sym.sum_axis(one_proxy_y, axis=0)
    one_feat = mx.sym.Reshape(one_feat, shape=(-1,))
    y = one_feat - one_proxy_y
    y = mx.sym.square(y)
    y = mx.sym.sum(y)
    y = -y

    z_y = mx.sym.broadcast_minus(z, y)
    z_y = mx.sym.exp(z_y) * tzM
    z_y = mx.sym.sum(z_y)
    z_y = z_y + min_value
    one_proxy_nca = mx.sym.log(z_y)

    proxy_ncas.append(one_proxy_nca)

  proxy_nca = mx.sym.Concat(*proxy_ncas, dim=0)
  reid_net = proxy_nca
  reid_net = mx.sym.MakeLoss(reid_net, name='proxy_nca_loss')

  return reid_net

```

i follow the setup step on http://mxnet.io/get_started/setup.html#install-the-mxnet-package-for-r.
Install MXNet for Python

To clone the MXNet source code repository to your computer, use git.

    # Install git if not already installed.
    sudo apt-get update
    sudo apt-get -y install git

Clone the MXNet source code repository to your computer, run the installation script, and refresh the environment variables. In addition to installing MXNet, the script installs all MXNet dependencies: Numpy, LibBLAS and OpenCV. It takes around 5 minutes to complete the installation.

    # Clone mxnet repository. In terminal, run the commands WITHOUT "sudo"
    git clone https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet.git ~/mxnet --recursive

    # If building with GPU, add configurations to config.mk file:
    cd ~/mxnet
    cp make/config.mk .
    echo "USE_CUDA=1" >>config.mk
    echo "USE_CUDA_PATH=/usr/local/cuda" >>config.mk
    echo "USE_CUDNN=1" >>config.mk

    # Install MXNet for Python with all required dependencies
    cd ~/mxnet/setup-utils
    bash install-mxnet-ubuntu-python.sh

    # We have added MXNet Python package path in your ~/.bashrc.
    # Run the following command to refresh environment variables.
    $ source ~/.bashrc

I think we should revert the code change and merge in the docs.

@piiswrong To fully fix this bug, it will be a big patch. All ops that forget to set `FListInputNames` properly suffer from this problem, because the default implementation of `FListInputNames` is return `{"data"}`. The basic idea of the patch is to separate parameters from inputs in op arguments. (`add_arguments()` to `add_input()`, `add_arguments()` to `add_params()`). In this way, we don't need `set_num_inputs()` and `FListInputNames` any more. What's your opinon?

I've found the problem :) If an `NDArrayIter` instance is used for training, `hard_reset()` must be applied to `NDArrayIter` before prediction.  `predict()` just calls `reset()` method which does not overcome the effect of `roll_over`.

I have also met this problem when I try to get an iterator following the [documentation of MNISTIter](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#mxnet.io.MNISTIter).  I use Python instead of R.

The code I used was:
```
import mxnet as mx

train_iter = mx.io.MNISTIter(image='./train-images-idx3-ubyte.gz',
        label='./train-labels-idx1-ubyte.gz',
        batch_size=16)
```
But I got the following error message:
>terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_alloc'
> what():  std::bad_alloc
>Aborted (core dumped)

At first I thought it was because the batch_size was too large, so I set a smaller batch_size. I still got the same error.

After reading this issue,  I realize that the MNIST data should be uncompressed first. 
After uncompressing the data, I run the following code:
```
import mxnet as mx

train_iter = mx.io.MNISTIter(image='./train-images-idx3-ubyte',
        label='./train-labels-idx1-ubyte',
        batch_size=16)
```
Then, everything is fine.  The output message is like this:
>[10:40:49] src/io/iter_mnist.cc:94: MNISTIter: load 60000 images, shuffle=1, shape=(16,1,28,28)

I think there is some ambiguity  for the parameter `image` and `label` in the [documentation of the MNISTIter](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html#mxnet.io.MNISTIter).  It would be clearer to state that the data and label of MNIST dataset should be uncompressed first before used by MNISTIter.
Problem solved by add `#define MSHADOW_USE_SSE 0` in prep_nnvm.sh and Makefile.

1. Same here. It's related to the image size. the symbols are bound each time a new image coming. 
2. The monitor is what you looking for. Or you can define some simple debug symbol.
@ysh329 , I met a similar problem when I tried to use MINISTIter, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2270 for a reference.
what was the problem?

I think the problem is that, by the time the executor is initialized, it doesn't have a monitor callback installed. If the monitor is installed later and runs forward(), the executor still performs the bulk execution. The pr doesn't fix the issue, I'll work on this later.
Thanks, I got it. It is the image size that varies the GPU memory usage. (I forget that the input size varies)
Use cuDNN version 5.1 (CUDA 8.0) instead of 5.0x (CUDA 7.5).

There is a slight  naming issue for the simple sampling operators in sample_op.cc:
The prior existing ones had been named "uniform" and "normal". Going forward with the same naming scheme would add "gamma", "poisson" etc. But "gamma" is already taken as an operator evaluating the gamma function. So decided to go with the naming scheme "random_uniform", "random_normal", random_gamma" which is a bit more expressive anyway. To preserve backward compatibility, there is an alias "uniform" for "random_uniform" and "normal" for "random_normal"

Hello Eric, 
after some tries I figured out the root cause of the compile problems:
These changes here need my recent change to mshadow/random.h. This change was integrated into mshadow with PR 228. But it seems that MxNet itself does not use this latest mshadow but instead a fixed older version. So I can't get this stuff here integrated as it will always fail compile.
Do you know a way how we can get this fixed?
you need to update submodule in your pr

Actually, yes. Basically I use a heuristic in which I group the samples to be added from A into contiguous locations at B, and for addition then I use slicing, for example like:
`            self.sourceArgument.gradientArray[source_tuple[0]:source_tuple[1] + 1] += \
                self.destinationArgument.gradientArray[destination_tuple[0]:destination_tuple[1] + 1]`
 and this clearly improves the performance compared to one by one adding.
Looks good!

Hi @mli @madjam @piiswrong  - I changed "bound" back to "binded" so that code could be merged in without breaking the universe. Can someone please take a look and make sure everything checks out and then merge in?

The input shape `x` is indeed `[timestep, minibatch, input dim]`. This is a fairly common convention for representing sequences. The weights are represented as a vector of floats. This is necessary because there is an unbounded number of possible weight matrices possible (as you can stack many layers together). I think MXNet recently got a converter that takes the flat vector and returns a dictionary of weight matrices and bias vectors.
@piiswrong Yes, it is already included.

Thanks to my colleague there was two steps I missed:

- Matrix transpose
- 4D conversion to fit the 122 rows of observation & 5 features.

train<-data.matrix(Datatrain)
train.x<-train[,-6]
train.y<-train[,6]
train.array <- t(train.x)
dim(train.array) <- c(1,5,1,122)
@mli Yes. It will automatically check whether code contains leading gap symbol.
@mli The accuracy numbers on https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification should be updated.

link to https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy-1.10.1/user/basics.broadcasting.html to explain how broadcasting is done

@madjam The issue for mxnet.io is we have multiple languages and each of them has different leading gap symbols. For languages other than python, leading gap symbol can't be picked out by simply calling "find('.go, .gp, .gt')", which is done by numpy.
@piiswrong I have added the numpy link to explain how broadcasting is done in broadcast_reduce_op_value.cc file
i'm going to merge this pr now. we can open another PR for other features
